abstract.para: The cluster administration tools like &crmshell; (&crmsh;) or &hawk; can be used by &rootuser; or any user in the group haclient. By default, these users have full read/write access. To limit access or assign more fine-grained access rights, you can use Access control lists (ACLs).

Access control lists consist of an ordered set of access rules. Each rule allows read or write access or denies access to a part of the cluster configuration. Rules are typically combined to produce a specific role, then users may be assigned to a role that matches their tasks.

note.title: CIB Syntax Validation Version and ACL Differences
note.para: This ACL documentation only applies if your CIB is validated with the CIB syntax version pacemaker-2.0 or higher. For details on how to check this and upgrade the CIB version, see .

If you have upgraded from &productname; 11 SPx and kept your former CIB version, refer to the Access Control List chapter in the &haguide; for &productname; 11 SP3 or earlier. It is available from &suse-onlinedoc;.

sect1.title: Requirements and Prerequisites
sect1.para: Before you start using ACLs on your cluster, make sure the following conditions are fulfilled:

listitem.para: Ensure you have the same users on all nodes in your cluster, either by using NIS, Active Directory, or by manually adding the same users to all nodes.
All users for whom you want to modify access rights with ACLs must belong to the haclient group.
All users need to run &crmsh; by its absolute path /usr/sbin/crm.
If non-privileged users want to run &crmsh;, their PATH variable needs to be extended with /usr/sbin.
ACLs are an optional feature. By default, use of ACLs is disabled.
If ACLs are not enabled, &rootuser; and all users belonging to the haclient group have full read/write access to the cluster configuration.
Even if ACLs are enabled and configured, both &rootuser; and the default CRM owner hacluster always have full access to the cluster configuration.

sect1.para: To use ACLs you need some knowledge about XPath. XPath is a language for selecting nodes in an XML document. Refer to or look into the specification at .

sect1.title: Enabling Use of ACLs In Your Cluster
sect1.para: Before you can start configuring ACLs, you need to enable use of ACLs. To do so, use the following command in the &crmsh;:

step.para: Start a Web browser and log in to the cluster as described in .
In the left navigation bar, select Cluster Properties.
In the CRM Configuration group, select the enable-acl attribute from the empty drop-down box and click the plus icon to add it.
To set enable-acl=true, activate the check box next to enable-acl and confirm your changes.

sect1.title: The Basics of ACLs
sect1.para: Access control lists consist of an ordered set of access rules. Each rule allows read or write access or denies access to a part of the cluster configuration. Rules are typically combined to produce a specific role, then users may be assigned to a role that matches their tasks. An ACL role is a set of rules which describe access rights to CIB. A rule consists of the following:

listitem.para: an access right like read, write, or deny
a specification where to apply the rule. This specification can be a type, an ID reference, or an XPath expression.

sect1.title: Configuring ACLs with &hawk;
sect1.para: The following procedure shows how to configure a read-only access to the cluster configuration by defining a monitor role and assigning it to a user. Alternatively, you can use &crmsh; to do so, as described in .

procedure.title: Adding a Monitor Role and Assigning a User with &hawk;

step.para: Start a Web browser and log in to the cluster as described in .

In the left navigation bar, select Access Control Lists. The view shows the Roles and Users taroth 2015-04-29: ACL Targets??? (bsc#921056) - check! taroth 2015-05-07:checked with SP4 RC1: Hawk UI still shows "Roles" and "Users", thus keeping steps below as there are now... that are already defined.
To define your ACL role(s):
Select the Roles category and click the plus icon.
Enter a unique Role ID, for example, monitor.
For our example of defining a monitor role, select read from the Right drop-down box.
In the Xpath text box, enter the Xpath expression /cib and click Create Role.
This creates a new role with name monitor, sets the read rights and applies it to all elements in the CIB by using the XPath expression/cib.
If necessary, you can add more access rights and XPath arguments by clicking the plus icon and specifying the respective parameters. Confirm your changes.
Assign the role to a user:
Select the Users category and click the plus icon.

The Create User view shows the available roles. It also contains an additional line for configuring individual ACL rules for that user. The view lets you either assign one or multiple roles to the user or define one or more individual rules for the user. Selecting a role will make the line for individual rules disappear and vice versa. Assigning a role plus individual rules is not possible.
Enter a unique User ID, for example, tux. Make sure this user belongs to the haclient group.
To assign a role to the user, select the respective entries from Roles. In our example, select the monitor role you have created.
To deselect one or multiple roles, click the respective entries once more. If no role is selected, the line for defining individual rules will appear again.

figure.title: &hawk;—Assigning a Role or Rule to a User

step.para: If you want to define individual rules instead, select a Right and enter the respective Xpath parameters for your rule. Click the plus icon to define additional rules.
Confirm your choice and assign the roles or rules to the user by clicking Create User.
